Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Excitatory insect toxins induce a spastic paralysis. They bind voltage-independently at site-4 of sodium channels (Nav) and shift the voltage of activation toward more negative potentials thereby affecting sodium channel activation and promoting spontaneous and repetitive firing (By similarity). Is lethal to mice. Is about 1% of the total protein in the venom. {ECO:0000250}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: This excitatory toxin inhibits insect calcium-activated potassium (KCa) channels (Slo-type). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P82228}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Acts by delaying the inactivation of presynaptic voltage-sensitive sodium channels (Nav). Acts against insects and causes a progressive spastic paralysis.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Insecticidal, cytolytic and antimicrobial peptide. Forms voltage-dependent, ion-permeable channels in membranes. At high concentration causes cell membrane lysis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: The heterotrimer blocks the voltage-dependent L-type calcium channels (Cav1/CACNA1) from the heart, and the small conductance calcium-activated potassium channels (KCa2/KCNN) in the chromaffin cells and in the brain. Is very toxic to mice. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15855042, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8901456, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9242659}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: May play a role in blocking voltage-gated potassium channels Kv1.1/KCNA1, Kv1.3/KCNA3 and Kv1.6/KCNA6. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23142506}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Blocks selectively the high conductance calcium-activated (maxi-K) potassium channels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C182}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Inhibits all known high-voltage activated calcium channels (L-, P/Q- and R-type currents) (Cav), and most effectively the P/Q- (Cav2.1/CACNA1A) and R-type (Cav2.3/CACNA1E) currents (PubMed:10884557). In rat brain, inhibits glutamate release, neuronal death and loss of neurotransmission in the hippocampus resulting from ischemia. In vivo, induces rapid general flaccid paralysis followed by death in 10-30 minutes at dose levels of 5 ug per mouse. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10884557, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11397544, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19370546, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8660275, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9351520, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9631431}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Binds to voltage-gated potassium channels Kv1.3/KCNA3 (IC(50)=0.48 uM) and Kv1.1/KCNA1 (IC(50)=6.7 uM) and inhibits channel activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23657660, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24189292}.

Organism: Stichodactyla haddoni (Saddle carpet anemone) (Haddon's sea anemone)
Protein names: Kappa-stichotoxin-Shd1a/kappa-stichotoxin-Shd1b (Kappa-SHTX-Shd1a/kappa-SHTX-Shd1b) (Kappa-AnmTX Sha 9a-1) (Potassium channel toxin SHTX I/SHTX II) (Potassium channel toxin SHTX-1/SHTX-2)
Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Kappa-stichotoxin-Shd1a: inhibits voltage-gated potassium channels (Kv).; FUNCTION: Kappa-stichotoxin-Shd1b: inhibits voltage-gated potassium channels (Kv). This toxin inhibits the binding of 125I-alpha-dendrotoxin to synaptosomal membranes (IC(50)=270 nM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18243416}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Potent inhibitor of Kv1/KCNA voltage-gated potassium channels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P59847}.

reviewed
reviewed

Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Probable neurotoxin with unknown target. Possibly targets ion channels. {ECO:0000305}.

Reviewed: reviewed
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Neurotoxin. Causes spastic paralysis and death in mice within 10 minutes at dose levels of 3 ug per mouse. {ECO:0000269|Ref.2, ECO:0000305}.

Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Omega-agatoxins are antagonists of voltage-gated calcium channels (Cav). {ECO:0000250}.

Organism: Agelenopsis aperta (North American funnel-web spider) (Agelenopsis gertschi)
Function [CC]: FUNCTION: Omega-agatoxins are antagonists of voltage-gated calcium channels. This toxin blocks calcium channels in insect central neurons but not at peripheral neuromuscular junctions. In vertebrates, it is broadly active against all high-threshold Cav1/CACNA1 channels and Cav2.2/CACNA1B channels.
